name: Alex
history: The patient has a history of substance abuse and has been through rehab to overcome it. He has had issues with his family, particularly with his mother, where he has felt rejected and emotionally neglected. He has struggled with obesity since childhood, which has affected his self-esteem and body image. He also has a history of being victimized and bullied due to his weight.
intermediate_belief:
Helpless: I'm just not very good at handling stress and I have poor self-control, which is why I need to not put myself in stressful situations. 
 Unlovable: If I show my true self, people will reject me the way my mother rejected me.
intermediate_belief_depression:
Helpless: There's nothing I can do to change my situation. I cannot control myself. 
Unlovable: I don't deserve to be happy, so why even try to stay clean?
coping_strategies: The patient has adopted avoidance as a coping strategy by distancing himself from his family to reduce exposure to negativity and conflict. He has started scheduling pleasant activities and planning his day ahead of time in order to maintain a sense of control over his emotions and circumstances.
situation: Alex's cousin invited him to attend his upcoming wedding.
auto_thought: It will be stressful and negative; people will ask me questions I cannot answer or don't want to answer; my mum would be ashamed of me and critical of me as always; They don't want me there anyway, nobody likes me in this family.
behavior: Ignored the invitation and did not respond to the RSVP request. Ignored phone calls from family.

name: Alex
history: The patient has a history of substance abuse and has been through rehab to overcome it. He has had issues with his family, particularly with his mother, where he has felt rejected and emotionally neglected. He has struggled with obesity since childhood, which has affected his self-esteem and body image. He also has a history of being victimized and bullied due to his weight.
intermediate_belief: Helpless: I'm just not very good at handling stress and I have poor self-control, which is why I need to not put myself in stressful situations.
intermediate_belief_depression: Helpless: There's nothing I can do to change my situation. I cannot control myself. So why stay clean anyway?
coping_strategies: The patient turns to substances as a coping strategy to escape his feelings. He has been staying at his girlfriend's place to avoid his parents' influence and the associated stress. He also uses yelling and stepping away from situations to manage his low self esteem.
situation: I missed my alarm and work up late for work.
auto_thought: Why can't I even do this little this right? My whole day is written off now, I might as well not do anything.
behavior: Called in sick. Got drunk in the morning and had a fight with girlfriend.

name: Alex
history: The patient has a history of substance abuse and has been through rehab to overcome it. coping_strategies: The patient turns to substances as a coping strategy to escape his feelings. situation: Was going to pick up girlfriend after work but it started raining just as he was about to walk out.
auto_thought: Why does this always happen to me? I'm a victim of bad luck.
behavior: Curses at the rain. Gave an excuse to girlfriend for not picking her up. Went back inside and had a beer. Calmed down and felt remorseful.

name: Blaise
history: Patient has been experiencing frustration, anxiety, and anger related to familial relationships. This is significantly influenced by a conversation regarding his wedding list with his parents, leading to insights about his feelings and actions similar to his father's pattern of seeking approval and unconditional love from family members who do not provide it.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am undesirable, unwanted.
I am bound to be abandoned.
I am bound to be alone.
intermediate_belief: Patient holds the belief that one must continuously seek familial approval and support to feel safe and valued. Patient also believes that investing in unhealthy familial relationships is necessary despite ongoing distress and frustration.
intermediate_belief_depression: During periods of low mood, the patient likely adopts more polarized views on family loyalty and support, feeling an increased sense of obligation to pursue approval, which exacerbates feelings of helplessness and rejection.
coping_strategies: Patient tends to engage in conversations with family members about emotional support and seeks to change family dynamics, though this is often met with resistance.
situation: Talk with parents about wedding list and encounter some disagreements on inviting certain family members.
auto_thought: If I do not make compromise to them, they will be angry. If they are angry they will abandon me.
behavior: Pretend to be happy with parents' suggestions. Go along with parents wishes. Decreased sleep. Worry and perseveration.

coping_strategies: Patient tends to engage in conversations with family members about emotional support and seeks to change family dynamics, though this is often met with resistance.
situation: Observing father's relentless pursuit of approval from his sister
auto_thought: Why can't I stop seeking approval in situations that I recognize as unhealthy? Am I a sick person just like my father?
behavior: Patterns of revisiting stressful relationships and workplace, seeking safety within family circle. Reassurance seeking.

auto_thought: I fear the loss of my father's support and struggle with his divided loyalties.
behavior: Voicing my perspective to my father about family dynamics, but finally give up. Adopts either passive or aggressive styles. Quickly apologizes for creating discord.

name: Caleb
history: The patient is a PhD candidate doing scientific research, with references to a study involving sequencing and a 'bright and shiny stone scientist' named Kelly. The patient appears to struggle with finishing projects, feeling as if the last bit of work is as significant as the entire project. The patient also mentions working on a project with a senior scientist who has struggled to gain recognition in his career.
intermediate_belief: If I don't complete my work perfectly or find something significant, I am not successful or competent.
intermediate_belief_depression: When I'm struggling with my work or feeling disconnected, it's because I'm not capable or deserving of success.
coping_strategies: The patient engages in activities like painting and meditating, which may serve as a healthy outlet for stress. They also seem to avoid intense work hours and choose to work when they feel like it, which could be an attempt to manage work-related stress.
situation: Working on a PhD project and feeling like it's not progressing as it should.
auto_thought: I should have finished by now. The last bit of work feels overwhelming and impossible to complete.
behavior: Avoids working consistent hours, gets distracted by other activities like painting.

name: Caleb
history: The patient is a PhD candidate doing scientific research, with references to a study involving sequencing and a 'bright and shiny stone scientist' named Kelly. The patient appears to struggle with finishing projects, feeling as if the last bit of work is as significant as the entire project. intermediate_belief: If I don't complete my work perfectly or find something significant, I am not successful or competent.

coping_strategies: The patient engages in activities like painting and meditating, which may serve as a healthy outlet for stress. They also seem to avoid intense work hours and choose to work when they feel like it, which could be an attempt to manage work-related stress. However, there is also evidence of ruminating about work and self, which can be an unhealthy coping mechanism.
situation: Comparing oneself to colleagues who work longer hours and publish more papers.
auto_thought: I'm not working hard enough, I'm not as good as they are.
behavior: Ruminates about perceived failures and inadequacies. Procrastinates (creates unhelpful cycle).

name: Jessa
history: Jessa has recently undergone shoulder surgery and is recovering from very painful processes. She is also dealing with additional pain, numbness, and tingling due to a herniated disc in her cervical spine. Jessa has a history of physical therapy due to an inability to walk and back issues. She has experienced being very ill in the past, which led to a significant period of being unable to walk and feeling down. After recovering, she started a new relationship, but her physical symptoms resurfaced.
intermediate_belief: Jessa tends to listen and believe people she perceives as smart or those who speak with conviction, treating their words as if they are always accurate or true. She also holds beliefs that she must find solutions and answers immediately, and becomes frustrated when things are not resolved quickly.
intermediate_belief_depression: During depressive episodes, Jessa believes that she will never be the same again and that her situation is permanent.
coping_strategies: She also seeks external validation and guidance from friends and professionals. When overwhelmed, she can fall into a state of hysteria, but she is learning to use humor and perspective-taking to calm herself down.
situation: Receiving an MRI report showing a herniated disc.
auto_thought: I'm too young to have a herniated disc. My life just never got easier. I'll probably suffer from all these issues forever.
behavior: Phoned therapist in a state of hysteria.

name: Jessa
history: Jessa has recently undergone shoulder surgery and is recovering from very painful processes. She is also dealing with additional pain, numbness, and tingling due to a herniated disc in her cervical spine. Jessa has a history of physical therapy due to an inability to walk and back issues. She has experienced being very ill in the past, which led to a significant period of being unable to walk and feeling down. After recovering, she started a new relationship, but her physical symptoms resurfaced.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am undesirable, unwanted.
I am bound to be abandoned.
intermediate_belief: Jessa believes she must appear strong and cheerful to be accepted and loved.
intermediate_belief_depression: During depressive episodes, Jessa believes that she will never be the same again and that her situation is permanent, people will eventually figure out she's actually very sick and everybody would leave her.
coping_strategies: Jessa utilizes avoidance by trying to put on a happy face and acting as if she's feeling okay.
situation: Having to put on a happy face at a Halloween party despite pain.
auto_thought: If I act as if I'm okay, others will like me and keep being friends with me. Nobody likes to stay around with very sick person.
behavior: Put on a happy face and avoided showing true feelings. Compared self with others at the party perceiving others as healthier and not distressed.

name: Chris
history: The patient has a history of working overseas and creating a website related to that work. He express a pattern of getting excited about new ideas but then becoming conflicted, losing confidence, and abandoning projects when encountering challenges. Additionally, the patient is dealing with issues related to his father, including writing a 'living letter' as part of his process of learning to forgive him.
unlovable_belief: I am undesirable, unwanted.
intermediate_belief: If I don't succeed in my projects or if people don't acknowledge my work, then it means I am not valued or desired. I need to be constantly validated by others to feel worthwhile.
intermediate_belief_depression: When I face challenges or feel stuck, it means I am failing and this confirms that I am undesirable or not good enough. Others' approval is the only measure of my success and worth.
coping_strategies: The patient uses fantasy as a coping mechanism to escape feelings of worthlessness and to seek a sense of acceptance and value. They also use social media for validation and rely on external feedback to feel appreciated. (all avoidance based strategies)
situation: Working on personal project of building a website.
auto_thought: I'm stuck with this project, maybe it's not worth continuing. I always get excited but then lose confidence.
behavior: Avoids continuing the project, engages in fantasy or seeks validation through social media.

He express a pattern of getting excited about new ideas but then becoming conflicted, losing confidence, and abandoning projects when encountering challenges. unlovable_belief: I am undesirable, unwanted.

situation: Reflecting on past successes and current challenges.
auto_thought: I've succeeded before without knowing the outcome, so I should keep going. But what if I fail again?
behavior: Becomes preoccupied with potential failure, may retreat into fantasy or avoid taking action.

name: Daisy
history: The patient is a 28-year-old student who has been trying to assert independence and self-sufficiency, particularly in financial matters, after returning from Egypt. The patient has previously relied on parents for support but is now attempting to take on more adult responsibilities such as paying bills, managing finances, and dealing with health insurance on her own for the first time. The patient's brother is still financially dependent on their parents, which the patient is consciously trying to avoid for herself.
intermediate_belief: I must do everything independently to prove that I am a capable adult and to avoid being a burden or like my brother.
intermediate_belief_depression: I have failed at independence and self-sufficiency, and I need to ask for help which makes me feel incompetent.
coping_strategies: The patient attempts to handle situations independently without relying on others, particularly parents. When faced with anxiety or uncertainty, the patient may act hastily or seek immediate resolution rather than waiting. The patient also aims to budget and handle finances alone, which is a form of asserting control and self-reliance.
situation: Contemplating asking parents for financial help.
auto_thought: I shouldn't need my parents' help at this age. I'm supposed to be independent.
behavior: Refusing parents' offers for help and trying to find affordable therapy options.

behavior: Expressing guilt and concern to the therapist about the payment discrepancy and the potential financial burden. Self criticism.

name: Bryce
history: The patient has a history of working long hours, similar to past experiences while touring, indicating a history of demanding work environments. The patient has also been dealing with unresolved issues with his father, including past abuse and a recent exchange of letters addressing this painful history. The patient's father's response to the letter appears to have been a significant event for the patient, potentially contributing to his current mental state.
intermediate_belief: The patient seems to hold the belief that work and productivity are essential to his self-worth and that idle time or personal development is wasted time. He also appears to believe that completing tasks and being acknowledged for his work is important for his value and self-esteem.
intermediate_belief_depression: During periods of depression, the patient may believe that he is not making progress in life and that his efforts are meaningless. This could lead to a lack of motivation to engage in activities and to complete tasks, further reinforcing feelings of inadequacy and worthless.
coping_strategies: The patient uses work as a coping strategy to feel productive and to reduce idle time, which he associates with negative feelings. He also use avoidance strategies when he perceives himself not productive and worthless, such as scrolling on social media.
situation: Contemplating the value and completion of his personal projects, such as building a website.
auto_thought: What's the point? No one will know it's me, and I'm not getting paid or acknowledged. I shouldn't do things for my own enjoyment.
behavior: Procrastinates on personal projects and engages in unfulfilling activities like social media scrolling.

situation: Reflecting on the use of idle time and personal development.
auto_thought: I should be more productive with my time. I'm not sure if I'm making the best use of it. If I don't use my time wisely I am a waste.
behavior: Struggles with choosing activities and often defaults to less fulfilling ones, leading to feelings of time wasted.

name: Ramona
history: The patient has experienced a traumatic incident involving a sexual assault by her partner, Ivan. This has led to a complex dynamic in their relationship, where trust and intimacy are significant issues. The patient has been working through these issues and has seen some improvement in the relationship dynamics, as Ivan has been making efforts to be more considerate and reestablish trust.
unlovable_belief: I am bound to be alone.
intermediate_belief: If I'm not in control, something bad will happen. I must be vigilant at all times to prevent being hurt again. People close to me may hurt me if I let my guard down.
intermediate_belief_depression: My efforts to rebuild trust may be futile. I might never be able to feel safe or loved again. I am at risk of being hurt even when things seem to be improving.
coping_strategies: The patient uses vigilance and control as a coping strategy to ensure her safety and prevent further harm.
situation: Recognizing improvements in Ivan's behavior, but feeling scared by the physical intimacy that is returning to the relationship.
auto_thought: Even though things are improving, I'm scared to be vulnerable again.
behavior: Engaging in physical intimacy with caution and the need for control. Freezes. Unable to initiate intimacy.

name: Ramona

situation: Ivan touching the patient in a way that reminds her of the past assault, triggering fear and uncertainty about his intent.
auto_thought: Is he going to hurt me again? Can I trust him not to repeat the past? I will get hurt. I can't trust him.
behavior: Confronting Ivan and discussing the incident, feeling a mix of hope and fear. Passive or aggressive confrontation to Ivan. Not assertive.

name: Fiona
history: The patient has a long-standing relationship with a friend named Jersey, who has undergone multiple surgeries due to her disabilities, including a below-the-knee amputation and knee replacement. The patient has been a supportive figure during Jersey's medical procedures and recovery but currently feels overwhelmed with her own life stresses. The patient also experiences conflict with her roommate, Ashby, regarding household issues.
unlovable_belief: I am undesirable, unwanted.
I am bound to be abandoned.
I am bound to be alone.
intermediate_belief: I should always try to help others and prioritize others' needs over myself.
intermediate_belief_depression: My efforts to help others are not enough, and I cannot manage my own life effectively when my friends are in trouble.
coping_strategies: The patient copes by trying to provide practical support, like cooking meals for friends in need, and by attempting to manage situations, like resolving cable service issues.
situation: Thinking about Jersey's surgery and recovery, but cannot offer help due to occupation with other things.
auto_thought: I'm really worried about her and feel bad because I can't be there for her as much as I want to.
behavior: Expresses concern, becomes tense and irritable, shows signs of avoidance, and struggles to sleep.

auto_thought: Why is she keeping neglecting my needs? I have always been helping her as much as I can!
behavior: Engages in minor arguments, but finally made compromise to her roommate.

name: Grace
history: The patient has recently gone through a divorce and is dealing with the associated challenges such as financial struggles, adjusting to single life, and co-parenting. The patient has also experienced a breakdown of several friendships due to the divorce and has a complicated relationship with her parents, which adds to the stress.
intermediate_belief: I must be independent and self-reliant to handle challenges. I must make everything in control.
intermediate_belief_depression: There are so many uncertanties in the future. I cannot handle them at all. I cannot stay independent and live on my own. I already lack the ability to stay independent after these many years' marrige.
coping_strategies: The patient uses social support by spending time with friends and seeking comfort in those relationships. The patient also attempts strategies like keeping busy and avoidance.
situation: Dealing with financial struggles and uncertainty after the divorce.
auto_thought: I don't know how I'm going to afford everything. I'm at the brink of not being able to pay for things.
behavior: Considers giving up her dog to save money, feels overwhelmed by financial paperwork and discussions. Ruminates and worries rather than effective problem solving.

name: Grace
history: The patient has recently gone through a divorce and is dealing with the associated challenges such as financial struggles, adjusting to single life, and co-parenting. The patient has also experienced a breakdown of several friendships due to the divorce and has a complicated relationship with her parents, which adds to the stress.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am bound to be abandoned.
I am bound to be alone.
intermediate_belief: If people know the real me or the details of my situation, they will not want to be my friend or support me. It's important to maintain a good image to be accepted.
intermediate_belief_depression: People will eventually find out the real me and the details of my situation. I will get abandoned by everybody.
coping_strategies: The patient tries to explain things to a few friends. The patient also attempts strategies like keeping busy and avoidance.
situation: Experiencing the breakdown of friendships following the divorce.
auto_thought: These friends don't want to be around me. Everybody just thinks I'm a bad person, and maybe that's true.
behavior: Withdraws from social gatherings, keep ruminating the divorce and the past.

auto_thought: They don't understand what I'm going through. They're critical and make me anxious about visiting them. Even my parents cannot support me.
behavior: Hesitates to communicate with parents, feels defensive and anticipates a difficult conversation with them.

name: Ian
history: The client has a history of feeling isolated and has been dealing with chronic depression since late adolescence. They have experienced frustration with friends and had a recent breakup that preceded a relapse into a depressive episode. The client has a history of taking SSRI and has recently been adjusting their medication regimen to deal with the relapse, which has been a source of additional stress.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am undesirable, unwanted.
I am bound to be alone.
intermediate_belief: If I can't manage my own feelings or make others understand me, then I'm failing. I should be able to handle my mental health better.
intermediate_belief_depression: When I'm depressed, nothing I do seems to make a difference. It feels like I'll never get better no matter what medication or strategies I try.
coping_strategies: Attempts to connect with friends for support, but this sometimes leads to further frustration when the interactions don't go as hoped.
situation: Trying to have a supportive conversation with a friend (Jamie) about mental health struggles.
auto_thought: She doesn't understand me and is treating me like a patient rather than a friend. She doesn't actually like me - she just doesn't want to show that. Nobody likes me.
behavior: Ends the conversation prematurely and feels dissatisfied with the interaction. Withdraws from further social interactions.

name: Ian
history: The client has a history of feeling isolated and has been dealing with chronic depression since late adolescence. The client has a history of taking SSRI and has recently been adjusting their medication regimen to deal with the relapse, which has been a source of additional stress.
intermediate_belief: If I can't manage my own feelings, then I'm failing. I should be able to handle my mental health better.
intermediate_belief_depression: When I'm depressed, nothing I do seems to make a difference. It feels like I'll never get better no matter what medication or strategies I try.
coping_strategies: Uses distraction techniques like watching TV, reading, and sewing, although these have been less effective lately.
situation: Planned to have a productive weekend sewing and doing some catch up work tasks.
auto_thought: I know how to do these things, It shouldn't be this hard. Why can't I even do such simple things?
behavior: Struggles to concentrate and becomes upset with the inability to perform familiar tasks, ended up watching TV all day.

name: Jay
history: Jay is a PhD student in a science field. Outside of work, Jay is deeply involved in music, having led a college band and now participates in a jazz group. He was recently offered a leadership position in the jazz group, but he declined because he was worried about not being able to manage the increased responsibility in addition to his mental health struggles and PhD work. The patient is struggling with his scientific work environment, feeling disconnected from his colleagues due to differing values and work habits. There seems to be a past experience of feeling connected and appreciated, which is now missing in his current environment.
intermediate_belief: If I am not able to excel in everything I do, then I am failing. I need to be recognized and appreciated by others to feel successful.
intermediate_belief_depression: When I'm not engaged in music or my work in a meaningful way, or when I'm not recognized for my efforts, I feel useless and like a failure. I believe my contributions are not valuable.
coping_strategies: Engaging in music and performance. The patient also seems to show avoidance of certain responsibilities and opportunities that may lead to additional stress.
situation: Getting stuck during jazz rehearsals with other performers and need to repeat many times.
auto_thought: I don't belong in a jazz improvisation context, my skills are not good enough, I'm still stuck here after many times' tries I'm just not good at this. I'm holding the group back.
behavior: Avoids practicing and fully committing to music, expresses doubt about his abilities.

name: Jay
history: Jay is a PhD student in a science field. Outside of work, Jay is deeply involved in music, having led a college band and now participates in a jazz group. He was recently offered a leadership position in the jazz group, but he declined because he was worried about not being able to manage the increased responsibility in addition to his mental health struggles and PhD work. The patient is struggling with his scientific work environment, feeling disconnected from his colleagues due to differing values and work habits. There seems to be a past experience of feeling connected and appreciated, which is now missing in his current environment.
intermediate_belief: If I am not able to excel in everything I do, then I am failing. I need to be recognized and appreciated by others to feel successful.
intermediate_belief_depression: When I'm not engaged in music or my work in a meaningful way, or when I'm not recognized for my efforts, I feel useless and like a failure. I believe my contributions are not valuable.
coping_strategies: Engaging in music and performance. The patient also seems to show avoidance of certain responsibilities and opportunities that may lead to additional stress.
situation: Being offered a leadership position in jazz group, although he wanted it, but felt unsure about being able to manage the responsibilities on top of everything. He finally turned down the opportunity.
auto_thought: I just cannot make it. I cannot make any advancement in music. I'm not even brave enough to take the challenge. I am a shameful failure. I would be too stressed and unable to manage.
behavior: Keep ruminating about the event.

name: Yvette
history: The patient has a significant life event of her aunt passing away without the patient fulfilling her aunt's last request. The patient was also not able to be with her aunt when she passed, which causes her persistent guilt. The patient was very close to her aunt, seeing her as the mother she wished she had, and her death has left a lasting impact. The patient also has a pattern of taking care of others at her own expense, and struggles with recognizing her own needs and allowing herself to experience fun and enjoyment.
worthless_belief: I am bad - dangerous, toxic, evil.
intermediate_belief: I am responsible for others and must fulfill others' expectations to validate my purpose in life. If I'm not meeting the needs of others, I'm a worthless person.
intermediate_belief_depression: I'm not meeting others' expectations. When I feel overwhelmed by my responsibilities, I'm a bad person and always hurting others like what I did to my aunt. It's shameful to think of prioritizing my own needs over others.
coping_strategies: The patient uses avoidance in confronting her grief and engages in overcommitment to helping others to compliment her inner grief and distress.
situation: Thinking about experiences with her aunt and not meeting her aunt's last request.
auto_thought: I didn't do what she wanted me to do, I failed her, and this can never be made up with. I am a bad person.
behavior: Keep ruminating about the past between her and her aunt.

name: Yvette
history: The patient has a significant life event of her aunt passing away without the patient fulfilling her aunt's last request. The patient was also not able to be with her aunt when she passed,  which causes her persistent guilt. The patient was very close to her aunt, seeing her as the mother she wished she had, and her death has left a lasting impact. The patient also has a pattern of taking care of others at her own expense, and struggles with recognizing her own needs and allowing herself to experience fun and enjoyment.
worthless_belief: I am bad - dangerous, toxic, evil.
intermediate_belief: I am responsible for others and must fulfill others' expectations to validate my purpose in life. If I'm not meeting the needs of others, I'm a worthless person.
intermediate_belief_depression: I'm not meeting others' expectations. When I feel overwhelmed by my responsibilities, I'm a bad person and always hurting others like what I did to my aunt. It's shameful to think of prioritizing my own needs over others.
coping_strategies: The patient uses avoidance in confronting her grief and engages in overcommitment to helping others to compliment her inner grief and distress.
situation: On the way to watch a movie but got a phone call from a friend seeking emotional support.
auto_thought: I need to skip the movie and support my friend, otherwise she would be greatly hurt. But I really want to watch the movie
behavior: Struggled but finally gave up the movie and talked with her friend for an hour. Feeling disappointed for giving up the movie.

name: Linda
history: The client has had significant life events that have impacted her current state, including losing her retirement funds on some poor financial decisions, which has led to financial concerns and the need to continue working potentially until an old age, find a new job that pays more, and/or find other ways to make money. Additionally, there are underlying tensions and unresolved feelings related to their family, particularly her mother and father, because now she is relying on them more for financial help.
intermediate_belief: I need to rely on family and friends to support my life. I am not able to handle anything out of my expectation by myself. My family and friends are supposed to always support me.
intermediate_belief_depression: I just cannot support myself. I am a failure and cannot even be independent. My future is hopeless. I cannot be trusted to take care of myself.
coping_strategies: Questioning the self; becoming easily defensive when feeling challenged or criticised for taking care of self; Show avoidance of making decisions or taking challenges in life, which in fact further increases anxious feelings.
situation: Reflecting on the financial loss due to poor financial decisions.
auto_thought: It's unfair that I can't retire. Why did this happened to me? I probably cannot support myself, I don't know what to do. Why won't my family help me more?
behavior: Expressing anger toward self, ruminating and regretting past decisions. Also angry at the family for not helping her more.

name: Linda
history: The client has had significant life events that have impacted her current state, including losing her retirement funds on some poor financial decisions, which has led to financial concerns and the need to continue working potentially until an old age, find a new job that pays more, and/or find other ways to make money. Additionally, there are underlying tensions and unresolved feelings related to their family, particularly her mother and father, because now she is relying on them more for financial help.
intermediate_belief: I need to rely on family and friends to support my life. I am not able to handle anything out of my expectation by myself. My family and friends are supposed to always support me.
intermediate_belief_depression: I just cannot support myself. I am a failure and cannot even be independent. My future is hopeless. I cannot be trusted to take care of myself.
coping_strategies: Questioning the self; becoming easily defensive when feeling challenged or criticised for taking care of self; Show avoidance of making decisions or taking challenges in life, which in fact further increases anxious feelings.
situation: Talking with parents about future plans and discussing the options of changing jobs.
auto_thought: I'm not capable of a better job, and I don't want to work that hard. Why won't my family help me more?
behavior: Feel pressured by family, lashing out and shouting at them to be more supportive.

name: Karen
history: The patient has a history of feeling underappreciated and unsupported in the workplace. She experiences challenges in her role, faces difficulties in getting her ideas and suggestions accepted, and struggles with coping in an environment that seems to dismiss her expertise and personal needs.
intermediate_belief: I must be valued and acknowledged from my colleagues to demonstrate my worth, if not, then I'm a worthless person. I must get support from my workplace, otherwise I'm trapped and helpless.
intermediate_belief_depression: My efforts are futile; my work is never good enough and will be criticized; Nobody acknowledges my value, I'm a worthless person.
coping_strategies: Avoidance of further commitment and effort towards mentorship goals, procrastination, wish to seek validation or acknowledgment for holding back on extreme action.
situation: A discussion was happening in the workplace about culture and atmosphere. Karen wanted to join, but her mentor had asked her to meet with a client at the same time, clashing with the discussion.
auto_thought: It doesn't matter if I go or not anyway because my thoughts aren't even that important.
behavior: Obliges with the client meeting, but disengages by going home early and not finishing her work for the day.

name: Karen
history: The patient has a history of feeling underappreciated and unsupported in the workplace. She experiences challenges in her role, faces difficulties in getting her ideas and suggestions accepted, and struggles with coping in an environment that seems to dismiss her expertise and personal needs.
intermediate_belief: I must be valued and acknowledged from my colleagues to demonstrate my worth, if not, then I'm a worthless person. I must get support from my workplace, otherwise I'm trapped and helpless.
intermediate_belief_depression: My efforts are futile; my work is never good enough and will be criticized; Nobody acknowledges my value, I'm a worthless person.
coping_strategies: Avoidance of further commitment and effort towards mentorship goals, procrastination, wish to seek validation or acknowledgment for holding back on extreme action.
situation: The colleagues praised the client's coworker for his hard work, and ask the client to help that coworker with technology issues.
auto_thought: My input and expertise are always overlooked and not harnessed.
behavior: Reluctantly helps colleagues with technology issues and ruminates on being underutilized.

name: Mason
history: The client has spent eleven months in Europe working on a project, which included creating a website and conducting interviews. This period appears important to the client and he's eager to show something for his efforts. The client has suffered from procrastination and anxiety in the past. He has managed to build structure into his life by implementing various strategies learned from a course and using reminders.
intermediate_belief: If I'm not productive or not doing anything significant, I'm wasting my life. I must keep up with the schedule. If I stay idle, then I'm failing.
intermediate_belief_depression: I just keep procrastinating and can never catch up with schedule. Failure is imminent. My project is going to fail due to my incompetency.
coping_strategies: The client uses structured daily routines with set times for reading, playing guitar, and going to the gym. He also sets reminders for tasks and have been trying to be present in the moment to reduce idle time, which he associates with being unproductive.
situation: Client is working on a project that is due soon. The project has had increased visibility due to a recent sociopolitical events related to the project's content.
auto_thought: I need to finish this asap. I have not finished the work that I need to put online, I'm behind schedule. I will fail on this project.
behavior: Rushes to work on the project, foregoes sleep, endures stress and extreme anxiety.

name: Mason
history: The client has spent eleven months in Europe working on a project, which included creating a website and conducting interviews. This period appears important to the client and he's eager to show something for his efforts. The client has suffered from procrastination and anxiety in the past. He has managed to build structure into his life by implementing various strategies learned from a course and using reminders.
intermediate_belief: I must always have something to show for my choices, actions and efforts, otherwise I'm a failure. I must always make the right choice. If I make the wrong choice, or stay idle, then I'm failing.
intermediate_belief_depression: Having options is paralyzing due to the pressure to make the perfect choice. I cannot make the right choice, I'm a failure.
coping_strategies: The client uses avoidance or procrastination when overwhelmed by decision making.
situation: Client think about their life choices and direction, dealing with ambiguity and too many options.
auto_thought: I can't make the wrong decision. I might fail or choose incorrectly, which could have serious implications for my life.
behavior: Client becomes paralyzed by options and fears making decisions, may engage in rumination.

name: Sarah
history: Sarah is in a significant relationship with her partner, Amelia, who has a rigorous schedule due to her clinical-based program, which keeps her busy and away from home for extended hours. Sarah often feels isolated during the week. Even though Sarah is incredibly busy, she feels like she has 'housewife' duties and takes care of all household tasks. Although she resents it, she has not brought it up to her partner. She has a history of attachment issues, starting from her childhood, where separation from her parents caused her distress. These issues have continued into adulthood, where she has struggled with separation anxiety and strong attachments to people in various contexts, such as summer camp, study abroad programs, and volunteer positions.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am undesirable, unwanted.
I am bound to be abandoned.
I am bound to be alone.
intermediate_belief: I need to be constantly engaged with people, otherwise I will be abandoned. I need to keep myself valuable to others and support others. I cannot live alone.
intermediate_belief_depression: People just don't care to stay in touch with me no matter how I try. Nobody loves me. I'm just a weak and needy person that cannot be independent.
coping_strategies: The client engages in various activities to cope with her feelings of loneliness and anxiety, such as running, cleaning, cooking, and sometimes picking Amelia up to spend more time with her. She experiences temporary relief from anxiety when in contact with Amelia. She keeps trying to stay connected with friends, but if they do not respond to her actively she will be more depressed and anxious.
situation: Not hearing from her partner Amelia throughout the day.
auto_thought: Something bad might have happened to her; she doesn't care to stay in touch with me; She doesn't love me.
behavior: Feeling unsettled, not at ease, unable to relax until she hears from Amelia. Texts Amelia, acts needy and clingy.

name: Sarah
history: Sarah is in a significant relationship with her partner, Amelia, who has a rigorous schedule due to her clinical-based program, which keeps her busy and away from home for extended hours. I am bound to be alone.

intermediate_belief_depression: People will just abandon me no matter how I try. Nobody loves me. I'm just a weak and needy person that cannot be independent.
coping_strategies: The client engages in various activities to cope with her feelings of loneliness and anxiety, such as running, cleaning, cooking, and sometimes picking Amelia up to spend more time with her. She tries to do household tasks as much as she can, so that to keep herself valuable to Amelia.
situation: Doing the laundry and thinking about the future of her relationship with Amelia and the domestic role she plays.
auto_thought: I don't like the role, but this is just what I'm capable of. If i don't do it I will lose Amelia.
behavior: Speculating about the relationship dynamic and feel trapped.

She experiences temporary relief from anxiety when in contact with Amelia. She keeps trying to stay connected with friends, but if they do not respond to her actively she will be more depressed and anxious.
situation: Keep trying to chat with a friend previously known at a summer camp, but that friend seems not interested and tend to get rid of her.
auto_thought: People keep getting rid of me. Nobody cares about me. I will be eventually alone.
behavior: Crying and seeking emotional support from Amelia.

name: Noah
history: The client has a past of academic challenges and underachievement despite noted intelligence. There was a negative college experience at Grinnell, which the client found to be isolated and disconnected from society, leading to dropping out and bitterness toward education. The client has not completed college, having about two years' worth of credits left. The client has a history of having high expectations set by the mother, and there seems to be a perceived failure to meet these. After some financial troubles, the client felt pressure from the mother to return home, further complicating the dynamic.
intermediate_belief: I must meet my parents' expectations, otherwise I'm a failure. I must work hard and stay productive to avoid failure.
intermediate_belief_depression: I'm not competent for anything. I keep failing to meet expectations of myself and others. I'm a worthless person.
coping_strategies: The client attempts to cope with feelings of inadequacy and fear of failure by controlling situations, making plans and being selective of the projects he undertakes. However, if they don't work well it will trigger stronger feeling of failure. There are traces of isolation, like secluding oneself to work, and probably procrastination as coping mechanisms.
situation: Experienced an unproductive week due to mistakes in planning. Comparing to client's sister's achievements and her ability to plan and organize time.
auto_thought: I'm a pathetic person. I'm never good at planning or organizing my time. I'm going to fail again, no wonder my parents are disappointed about me.
behavior: Acknowledges the week was unproductive, ultimately feeling like a failure.

name: Noah
history: The client has a past of academic challenges and underachievement despite noted intelligence. There was a negative college experience at Grinnell, which the client found to be isolated and disconnected from society, leading to dropping out and bitterness toward education. The client has not completed college, having about two years' worth of credits left. The client has a history of having high expectations set by the mother, and there seems to be a perceived failure to meet these. After some financial troubles, the client felt pressure from the mother to return home, further complicating the dynamic.
intermediate_belief: I must meet my parents' expectations, otherwise I'm a failure. I must meet my academic and career goals and my own expectations to demonstrate my worth.
intermediate_belief_depression: I'm not competent for anything. I keep failing to meet expectations of myself and others. I'm a worthless person.
coping_strategies: The client shows avoidance of certain responsibilities or actions that might trigger feelings of failure, such as looking for a job opportunity. There are traces of isolation, like secluding oneself to work, and probably procrastination as coping mechanisms.
situation: Seeking help from parents due to financial troubles, and mentioned the college dropout experience during the talk.
auto_thought: I cannot finish college due to my incompetency, and need to rely on parents for a living. I'm so pathetic and a failure.
behavior: Keep ruminating about the past and inactive for future plans.

name: Rachel
history: The patient, named Rachel, has a history of relationship problems, including with her current husband, Ivan, and work-related stress. She has demonstrated a pattern of self-critical thoughts, particularly around her value in relationships and her professional achievements. She also appears to feel a significant burden of responsibility, as shown in the dynamics with her sister, Emma, who has typically assumed a caring role for Rachel. Her father's successful career and work ethic have shaped her expectations and self-view, and she often feels Ivan doesn't work hard enough. She was also recently laid off and is having a hard time finding a new job.
intermediate_belief: Being ambitious and successful in career is a crucial component of a fulfilling life. If one is not successful in career or not ambitious enough, he's a failure.
intermediate_belief_depression: My efforts towards job seeking are futile, I cannot be successful in my career, so I'm a failure. My marriage is also a failure, because my husband is not ambitious enough to make progress in his career as expected.
coping_strategies: The coping strategies Rachel mentions include volunteering for roles related to her field of interest, applying for jobs, seeking therapy, and possibly socializing with her sister. However, she also displays unhealthy coping mechanisms such as self-criticism and emotional reasoning.
situation: Thinking about her and her husband Ivan's careers.
auto_thought: I cannot finish college due to my incompetency, and need to rely on parents for a living. I'm so pathetic and a failure. My husband is also a failure.
behavior: Struggling with conflicting feelings about husband's job, questioning her own beliefs about success and fulfillment.

name: Rachel
history: The patient, named Rachel, has a history of relationship problems, including with her current husband, Ivan, and work-related stress. She has demonstrated a pattern of self-critical thoughts, particularly around her value in relationships and her professional achievements. However, she also displays unhealthy coping mechanisms such as self-criticism and emotional reasoning.
situation: Dealing with the job-seeking process and getting a rejection email.
auto_thought: I'm never going to find a job, I'm failing in my job search, it's all pointless.
behavior: Decreased motivation to continue job search, feeling overwhelmed and hopeless.

name: Patrick
history: The patient has experienced issues with micromanagement at work in both their current and previous job positions. They have a history of feeling blamed and experiencing situations where they have little to no control and being criticized for it, contributing to a sense of helplessness and potentially lowering self-efficacy in their professional life.
intermediate_belief: I must be acknowledged and treated fairly by colleagues which demonstrate I'm competent for my work, if not, then I'm not competent. I must try every effort to take responsibility for everything, to meet the expectations of my colleagues.
intermediate_belief_depression: My colleagues just keep criticizing me. Maybe those mistakes are really my responsibility, I'm just not competent for this work. Or they just use me as a scapegoat because I'm weak and powerless and don't know how to fight back. I'm trapped and hopeless.
coping_strategies: The client points out mistakes in management to alleviate blame, takes initiative to manage a heavy workload effectively, employs self-distraction, and engages in social activities and role plays to cope with stress and the feeling of being overwhelmed. However, the client also tends to work too hard, to overload himself, with the hope of meeting others' expectations, while having a lot of self criticism.
situation: Being blamed for spreadsheet errors at work that are not the client's fault.
auto_thought: There is too much pressure on me to fix something I didn't cause. I'm a weak and powerless person and don't know how to deal with scapegoating, so they keep bullying me.
behavior: Trying to explain the situation to their boss, feeling frustrated and discouraged at work.

name: Patrick
history: The patient has experienced issues with micromanagement at work in both their current and previous job positions. They have a history of feeling blamed and experiencing situations where they have little to no control and being criticized for it, contributing to a sense of helplessness and potentially lowering self-efficacy in their professional life.
intermediate_belief: I must be acknowledged and treated fairly by colleagues which demonstrate I'm competent for my work, if not, then I'm not competent. I must try every effort to take responsibility for everything, to meet the expectations of my colleagues.
intermediate_belief_depression: My colleagues just keep criticizing me. Maybe those mistakes are really my responsibility, I'm just not competent for this work. I'm trapped and hopeless.
coping_strategies: The client points out mistakes in management to alleviate blame, takes initiative to manage a heavy workload effectively, employs self-distraction, and engages in social activities and role plays to cope with stress and the feeling of being overwhelmed. However, the client also tends to work too hard, to overload himself, with the hope of meeting others' expectations, while having a lot of self criticism.
situation: Encountering micromanagement at work.
auto_thought: My efforts are never enough. I'm never meeting their expectations. I'm just not competent for this job.
behavior: Ruminating about past experiences of micromanagement, blaming themself, and considering quitting the job.

name: Talia
history: The patient has a significant history of family conflict, particularly with her father who was described as cruel, dismissive, and unsupportive. The patient's relationship with her father has deteriorated to the point of estrangement, and similar themes of familial conflict are reflected in her experiences with her partner's family. The patient reports feeling unsupported and mistreated by her partner's sister-in-law, Candace, which appears to be causing a significant amount of stress and frustration. The pressure to conform to the expectations of her partner's family and to tolerate Candace's behavior without recourse is reminiscent of her history with her own family and her inability to effectively confront or manage these familial relationships.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am undesirable, unwanted.
I am bound to be abandoned.
intermediate_belief: I must maintain peace and accept family members as they are, even if they treat me poorly. If I have conflicts with family members, I cannot win them, and it will only make everybody abandon me, or make the whole family torn apart.
intermediate_belief_depression: If I stand up for myself, it will only make situations worse and I will be the one causing drama within the family. I'm powerless in this family and they will not support me. But I'm getting more and more upset by being offended by Candace. I don't know what to do. I'm just a weak person and trapped.
coping_strategies: Avoiding confrontation with family members, withdrawing from situations that may lead to conflict, considering reducing time spent with the family or specific family members, looking for support from friends.
situation: Thinking about family vacation in Maine and interacting with Candace.
auto_thought: Candace will treat me poorly, and I won't be able to stand up for myself without disrupting the family dynamic.
behavior: Feels anxious about upcoming family events, procrastinates on work, loses sleep.

name: Talia

I'm powerless in this family and they will not support me. But I'm getting more and more upset by being offended by Candace. I don't know what to do. I'm just a weak person and trapped.
coping_strategies: Avoiding confrontation with family members, withdrawing from situations that may lead to conflict, considering reducing time spent with the family or specific family members, looking for support from friends.
situation: Considering how to handle Candace's rude behavior
auto_thought: If I confront Candace, it will make things worse, but if I don't, I'll continue to be treated poorly.
behavior: Ruminates on past interactions with Candace; struggles with deciding to set boundaries.

name: Wendy
history: The patient has been dealing with complex interpersonal relations, particularly with a significant other named Ivan and his family. A series of betrayals and trust issues have recently emerged from Ivan, and his family seems to avoid taking intervention in these matters. The patient has been actively involved with the family but feels anger and betrayal due to their recent actions and avoidance.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am bound to be abandoned.
intermediate_belief: My partner should never betray or deceive me. If it happened, the harm will never be remedied.
intermediate_belief_depression: Betrayal and deceit will happen at any time, even people who say love me will lie and hurt me eventually. There's no trust left between Ivan and I. There's no solution to everything and I'm helpless and trapped
coping_strategies: Wendy copes with by being on high alert of any suspicious behaviors or red flags from Ivan; and has resorted to checking his phone and tracking his location. Wendy also goes to therapy and seems willing to engage in change.
situation: Finding out Ivan booked a trip without telling her, triggering memories of past betrayals.
auto_thought: He is hiding things again, I cannot trust him, this is just like the past betrayals. This will happen over and over again.
behavior: Confronts Ivan leading to a fight, scrutinizes his explanations, and remains vigilant.

name: Wendy
history: The patient has been dealing with complex interpersonal relations, particularly with a significant other named Ivan and his family. A series of betrayals and trust issues have recently emerged from Ivan, and his family seems to avoid taking intervention in these matters. The patient has been actively involved with the family but feels anger and betrayal due to their recent actions and avoidance.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am bound to be abandoned.
intermediate_belief: I must keep good peace with family members and get support from them, otherwise I'm helpless and trapped. My partner should never betray or deceive me. If it happened, the harm will never be remedied.
intermediate_belief_depression: Betrayal and deceit will happen at any time, even people who say love me will lie and hurt me eventually. There's no trust left between Ivan and I. Nobody in this family is supporting me. There's no solution to everything and I'm helpless and trapped
coping_strategies: Wendy copes with by being on high alert of any suspicious behaviors or red flags from Ivan; and has resorted to checking his phone and tracking his location. Wendy also goes to therapy and seems willing to engage in change.
situation: Interacting with Ivan's family. The mother makes a comment like 'boys will be boys' and asks Wendy to 'forgive and forget'.
auto_thought: They must be blaming me for not being 'over' the past, they are taking his side unfairly. They don't support me and think I'm being dramatic.
behavior: Keep ruminating the past betrayals and have conflicting thoughts regarding the family. Lose sleep. Fantasizes about standing up to the family and telling them off.

name: Ashley
history: The patient has experienced ongoing interactions with her mother that are stressful and controlling, leading to feelings of passivity and helplessness. The reported family dynamic, particularly the communication style and delayed sharing of significant events, adds to this stress. Also, the patient's emotional responses and behavior during her parents' visit suggest a history of such dynamics affecting them over time.
unlovable_belief: I am unlovable.
I am bound to be abandoned.
intermediate_belief: My feelings and needs are secondary or less valid than others', I must manage situations to avoid conflict or to maintain peace with my parents. It is safer not to express myself and my emotions, otherwise I will be abandoned. I don't have the power and strength to stand up for myself.
intermediate_belief_depression: My feelings and needs are never seen or supported by my parents. I'm powerless and weak when confronting my parents. it is inevitable that interacting with my family will leave me feeling miserable and invalidated. But if I just keep detached and numb, my emotions will be too overwhelming once they burst out. I'm gradually losing control of myself and can't control my emotions. I don't know what to do and trapped.
coping_strategies: The patient uses avoidance (declining invitations from friends, not wanting to talk to parents about her actual feelings) and emotional numbing (feeling 'out of it' and 'zoning out') as ways to cope with the stress and unhappiness related to family interactions. They also seem to employ distraction and passive acceptance of the situation.
situation: Planning for parents' visit and navigating her presence.
auto_thought: No matter what I do, my needs and wishes are ignored or overruled.
behavior: Becomes passively involved in the visit, avoids direct confrontation and communications. Trying to suppress feelings.

situation: Having a conflicting discussion with mother over weekend plans and financial assistance.
auto_thought: My mother will always control the situation, I can't assert myself without risking conflict. I cannot win the conflict.
behavior: Accepts mother's decisions, begrudgingly allows her to pay for purchases and feels conflicted about it. Suppress emotions and numb herself.

situation: Encountering disagreements with parents at dinner and getting suppressed by mother again.
auto_thought: I'm the only one reacting emotionally; my emotions are not valid here. I'm losing control of myself and everything will be over!
behavior: Tries to suppress emotional reactions and feels detached, cries alone later instead of discussing feelings with parents.

name: Evan
history: The patient has a history of experiencing feelings of inadequacy, performance pressure, and social disappointment. He recalls past instances where he tried to put on a performance to meet others' expectations and hide his vulnerability. He recently encountered an incident that caused one of his businesses to fail, which resulted in financial difficulty.
unlovable_belief: I am undesirable, unwanted.
I am bound to be abandoned.
intermediate_belief: I must meet others' expectations. Expressing weaknesses or asking for help is frowned upon and not beneficial. I need to have a facade of control or a performance to be accepted or to interact socially. Discussing problems is pointless and signs of weakness must be hidden, otherwise nobody likes me and I will be abandoned.
intermediate_belief_depression: If I'm failing to meet expectations, or showing my vulnerability and weakeness, people will know I'm just a weak person and a failure. I will eventually be unwanted and abandoned.
coping_strategies: The patient uses avoidance (e.g., not attending gatherings), suppression of emotions, and intellectualization as coping methods. He also engages in counterproductive self-talk, pseudo-performances in social interactions, and rationalization to avoid showing vulnerability. He also uses grandiosity and masculinity to cover up his insecurities.
situation: Being invited to visit his sister but currently being financially unstable.
auto_thought: I can't afford it, and it would be admitting weakness to tell the truth. Going would show support but it's just too stressful for me. I can't let them know I don't have enough money.
behavior: Declines sister's invitation and lies to her about the reason, ruminates on financial instability. Lies about purchasing a designer watch to family, to cover up his financial issues.

situation: Took out a loan instead of asking family or friends for help.
auto_thought: I can't let anyone know I'm struggling financially because they'll lose respect for me.
behavior: Brags to his business acquaintances about a crazy weekend in Las Vegas and how much money he spent, which was a lie and didn't actually happen; in order to cover up his anxiety and insecurity.

situation: Cried about the recent failure of a business and the financial difficulty resulted, considering talking to family members for support.
auto_thought: I just failed the expectations of everybody. I shouldn't show vulnerability to anyone.
behavior: Crying and keep ruminating. Avoid calls or interactions from family members.

name: Zac
history: The patient works in an educational setting with children with learning disabilities. The patient has had a history of being babied by his parents, facing little punishment or consequences for his actions, leading to conflicts with authority and frustration when things don't go his way. He has been frustrated by the difference between his expectations and reality both in his job and personal life.
intermediate_belief: My efforts must have desired impact. I must have authority and influence, otherwise I'm a failure. The changes I make must proceed smoothly.
intermediate_belief_depression: My efforts in both work and life are unproductive and futile, I'm powerless and ineffective in everything. I'm a failure.
coping_strategies: The patient tends to become frustrated and angry, yet internally conceals these feelings. He uses verbal self-expression to relieve frustration and are aware of his tendency to erupt like a 'volcano' and talk to himself as a form of coping.
situation: Handling students with learning disabilities and trying to encourage them to socialize and perform activities on campus. However it did not work very well as expected.
auto_thought: I'm not being productive, my effort is meaningless, I feel like a failure in my role.
behavior: Ruminates on all the times he's failed in his work-related efforts. Considers quitting his job.

situation: Proposed a new method for teaching students, but got rejected by the school leadership.
auto_thought: I don't have any authority and just keep failing. I hate the feeling of powerless, but I indeed am.
behavior: Show reluctance for work and communication. Keep talking about the unreasonable decision of the school leadership. Doesn't directly confront school leadership, but acts secretly defiant and spiteful.

situation: Talked to a friend about recent frustrations, and the friend mentioned his tendency of controlling behavior.
auto_thought: Even my friend thinks I'm a failure. And he even thinks I'm a 'giant baby'. How offensive!
behavior: Decided that this friend was no longer a good friend. Acts cold towards the friend, intentionally ignores texts from this friend and purposefully doesn't invite them to a group gathering.
